articles.headline: For Children, Dumbed-Down Phones May Be Smartest Option
articles.snippet: Since most new phones come with Internet access, parents need to plan carefully to find devices that allow only texting and talking. Or they need to make use of a smartphone’s parental controls.
articles.abstract: Since most new phones come with Internet access, parents need to plan carefully to find devices that allow only texting and talking. Or they need to make use of a smartphone’s parental controls.
articles.lead_paragraph: The logic seems simple, impeccable even.

articles.headline: In Rape Case of Oklahoma Officer, Victims Hope Conviction Will Aid Cause
articles.snippet: Two of Daniel Holtzclaw’s victims described their horror over the assaults, as the verdict was met with praise for the jury but outrage with a system that failed to protect poor black women.
articles.abstract: Two of Daniel Holtzclaw’s victims described their horror over the assaults, as the verdict was met with praise for the jury but outrage with a system that failed to protect poor black women.
articles.lead_paragraph: OKLAHOMA CITY — Jannie Ligons stood at a news conference microphone on Friday and described her horror and defenselessness as an Oklahoma City police officer sexually assaulted her in her car during a traffic stop.
articles.byline: By Ben Fenwick and Alan Schwarz

articles.headline: San Bernardino Attackers’ Friend Spoke of ‘Sleeper Cells’ Before Rampage
articles.snippet: Enrique Marquez is the crucial if unlikely figure in the rampage investigation. Acquaintances say he often used to talk about sleeper terrorist cells.
articles.abstract: Enrique Marquez is the crucial if unlikely figure in the rampage investigation. Acquaintances say he often used to talk about sleeper terrorist cells.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIVERSIDE, Calif. — The regulars did not take it seriously when Enrique Marquez mused about terrorism at Morgan’s Tavern, a dank dive bar where Mr. Marquez hauled ice, cleaned bathrooms and checked IDs at the door. After a few drinks, he would just start talking — about his money woes, trying to lose weight, wanting to join the Navy. News reports about terrorism were just fodder for more bar talk.
articles.byline: By Ian Lovett, Jack Healy, Michael S. Schmidt and Julie Turkewitz

articles.headline: Attack Spurs New Chapter in History of Dread in the U.S.
articles.snippet: In interviews, even Americans who deplore Donald J. Trump’s call to ban Muslim immigrants are more fearful after the rampage in California.
articles.abstract: In interviews, even Americans who deplore Donald J. Trump’s call to ban Muslim immigrants are more fearful after the rampage in California.
articles.lead_paragraph: The handsome Washington townhouse where Wayne Hickory practices orthodontics is a landmark of terrorism in America.

articles.headline: Martin Shkreli’s Latest Plan to Sharply Raise Drug Price Prompts Outcry
articles.snippet: Critics say that Turing, the pharmaceutical led by Mr. Shkreli, is exploiting a program that awards vouchers that can be sold at huge profits while pricing drugs out of patients’ reach.
articles.abstract: Critics say that Turing, the pharmaceutical led by Mr. Shkreli, is exploiting a program that awards vouchers that can be sold at huge profits while pricing drugs out of patients’ reach.
articles.lead_paragraph: Martin Shkreli is once again provoking alarm with a plan to sharply increase the price of a decades-old drug for a serious infectious disease. This time the drug treats Chagas disease, a parasitic infection that can cause potentially lethal heart problems.

articles.headline: Draft of Climate Pact Is Ready, U.N. Officials Say
articles.snippet: Officials said negotiators in Paris had agreed on new language for a pact that will be presented Saturday to diplomats from 195 nations.
articles.abstract: Officials said negotiators in Paris had agreed on new language for a pact that will be presented Saturday to diplomats from 195 nations.
articles.lead_paragraph: LE BOURGET, France — After almost two weeks of marathon negotiations, the lines for food and coffee on Friday night snaked through the temporary tent city here that has been home to the global climate talks. People made final bets in a five-euro pool on the precise hour the talks might conclude.

articles.headline: A Junk Bond Fund Freezes Out Investors, and the Chills Spread
articles.snippet: The step by Third Avenue Management to put the Focused Credit Fund into a liquidating trust and sell its assets over the course of a year or so was a rude surprise to its investors.
articles.abstract: The step by Third Avenue Management to put the Focused Credit Fund into a liquidating trust and sell its assets over the course of a year or so was a rude surprise to its investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two months ago, Thomas Lapointe, lead portfolio manager of the Third Avenue Management junk bond fund, delivered a bullish presentation at a conference at the Waldorf Astoria hotel.

articles.headline: Nations Approve Landmark Climate Accord in Paris
articles.snippet: The deal, which required unanimous approval by delegates from around the world, will for the first time commit nearly every country to lowering greenhouse gas emissions.
articles.abstract: The deal, which required unanimous approval by delegates from around the world, will for the first time commit nearly every country to lowering greenhouse gas emissions.
articles.lead_paragraph: LE BOURGET, France — With the sudden bang of a gavel Saturday night, representatives of 195 nations reached a landmark accord that will, for the first time, commit nearly every country to lowering planet-warming greenhouse gas emissions to help stave off the most drastic effects of climate change.

articles.headline: Fannie and Freddie’s Government Rescue Has Come With Claws
articles.snippet: Since 2008, the mortgage giants have been held to far more punishing standards than the big banks, opening the door to an attempted Wall Street takeover.
articles.abstract: Since 2008, the mortgage giants have been held to far more punishing standards than the big banks, opening the door to an attempted Wall Street takeover.
articles.lead_paragraph: On May 9, 2012, the executives of Fannie Mae, the beleaguered mortgage finance company, finally went public with good news: After three and a half years as a ward of the state, it was profitable again.

articles.headline: ‘A Whole New Being’: How Kricket Nimmons Seized the Transgender Moment
articles.snippet: After a rocky life in the South, a Brooklyn resident became one of the first New Yorkers to undergo gender reassignment surgery paid for by Medicaid.
articles.abstract: After a rocky life in the South, a Brooklyn resident became one of the first New Yorkers to undergo gender reassignment surgery paid for by Medicaid.
articles.lead_paragraph: Perched on a gurney at dawn, Kricket Jerná Nimmons, 40, kicked her feet giddily, like a girl on the edge of a pool, preparing to take a plunge. She wore a hospital gown and purple socks with paw prints. Her face was clean-scrubbed — “no lash, no makeup, just me” — and she looked at peace.

articles.headline: Alan Dershowitz on the Defense (His Own)
articles.snippet: Helping a friend accused of sexual offenses led to accusations of misconduct against the prominent lawyer Alan Dershowitz. Now he’s fighting to clear his name.
articles.abstract: Helping a friend accused of sexual offenses led to accusations of misconduct against the prominent lawyer Alan Dershowitz. Now he’s fighting to clear his name.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last month, demonstrators at Johns Hopkins University interrupted Alan M. Dershowitz as he was giving a fiery speech defending Israel. The disruption normally would not have fazed Mr. Dershowitz, a former Harvard Law School professor who thrives on controversy and relishes taking on opponents in and out of the courtroom.

articles.headline: U.S. Visa Process Missed San Bernardino Wife’s Online Zealotry
articles.snippet: Tashfeen Malik passed three background checks by American immigration officials but none uncovered what she had said online about her views on violent jihad.
articles.abstract: Tashfeen Malik passed three background checks by American immigration officials but none uncovered what she had said online about her views on violent jihad.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Tashfeen Malik, who with her husband carried out the massacre in San Bernardino, Calif., passed three background checks by American immigration officials as she moved to the United States from Pakistan. None uncovered what Ms. Malik had said online about her views on violent jihad.
articles.byline: By Matt Apuzzo, Michael S. Schmidt and Julia Preston

articles.headline: Moms and Daughters Debate Gender Factor in Hillary Clinton’s Bid
articles.snippet: In a renewed effort to attract younger women to her campaign, Hillary Clinton is now more intent on trying to forge common cause on specific issues, and less on merely shattering the glass ceiling.
articles.abstract: In a renewed effort to attract younger women to her campaign, Hillary Clinton is now more intent on trying to forge common cause on specific issues, and less on merely shattering the glass ceiling.
articles.lead_paragraph: Barbara Schierenbeck, a 59-year-old nurse in Brooklyn, is swept up in the excitement of potentially electing Hillary Clinton the first female president. She cannot understand why her 19-year-old daughter, Anna, does not feel the same way.
articles.byline: By Amy Chozick and Yamiche Alcindor

articles.headline: Smart Car Standoff Pits Social Progress Against Global Competition
articles.snippet: At a Smart car factory, workers are being asked to increase their workweek for no additional pay, with the threat of plant relocation hanging over them.
articles.abstract: At a Smart car factory, workers are being asked to increase their workweek for no additional pay, with the threat of plant relocation hanging over them.
articles.lead_paragraph: HAMBACH, France — On a drizzly afternoon in October, Mathis Cédric buzzed around the kitchen of his small Alsatian restaurant in Hambach, France, a bucolic town near the German border. It was lunchtime, and workers from a nearby Smart car factory would soon be filtering in to grab the daily special of sauerkraut and sausages before heading to their afternoon shift.

articles.headline: With Fed Set to Lift Interest Rates, the Little Guy Feels Anxious
articles.snippet: Denver’s economy has enjoyed one of the nation’s strongest rebounds from the recession and is now at the center of a tech start-up boom. Yet the mood is fragile.
articles.abstract: Denver’s economy has enjoyed one of the nation’s strongest rebounds from the recession and is now at the center of a tech start-up boom. Yet the mood is fragile.
articles.lead_paragraph: AURORA, Colo. — William Harris tapped his retirement savings to open A-Town Pizza, a Neapolitan pizzeria, in this Denver suburb three years ago. He borrowed $200,000 to open a second location this year and now employs 60 people. On a good Friday, his shops sell 1,200 pies.

articles.headline: Seattle Considers Measure to Let Uber and Lyft Drivers Unionize
articles.snippet: The Seattle City Council plans to vote on a proposed law to give freelance, on-demand drivers the right to collectively negotiate on pay and working conditions.
articles.abstract: The Seattle City Council plans to vote on a proposed law to give freelance, on-demand drivers the right to collectively negotiate on pay and working conditions.
articles.lead_paragraph: After burning out the clutch on his Kia Soul last year, Don Creery bought a new car with an automatic transmission. He went into debt for the vehicle because he considered it an investment: He had just started driving full time in Seattle for Lyft and Uber, the ride-hailing start-ups, and was making money.
articles.byline: By Mike Isaac, Nick Wingfield and Noam Scheiber

articles.headline: As Economy Lags, Hugo Chávez’s Movement Fades in Venezuela
articles.snippet: Last week, in a gut blow for the movement known as Chavismo, Venezuela turned raw anger over economic hardship into a landslide victory for the political opposition in crucial elections.
articles.abstract: Last week, in a gut blow for the movement known as Chavismo, Venezuela turned raw anger over economic hardship into a landslide victory for the political opposition in crucial elections.
articles.lead_paragraph: BARINAS, Venezuela — As president, Hugo Chávez lavished millions from this country’s oil boom on his home state of Barinas. He built a soccer stadium, highways, apartment houses and a hospital. He sang Barinas’s songs, danced its folk dances on television and rode with its cowboys over its open plains.

articles.headline: Howard University May Sell Rights to Its Public TV Station’s Spectrum
articles.snippet: The sale could bolster other parts of the financially struggling university, but it could also mean the end of WHUT, the 35-year-old public television station that is the first owned and operated by a historically black institution.
articles.abstract: The sale could bolster other parts of the financially struggling university, but it could also mean the end of WHUT, the 35-year-old public television station that is the first owned and operated by a historically black institution.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Howard University Television crackled onto the airwaves here in November 1980, hundreds of people representing the city, university and broadcasting industry turned out to celebrate the first of its kind: a public television station owned and operated by a historically black institution.

articles.headline: For Pandora, Ruling on Streaming Royalty Rates Is Crucial
articles.snippet: An increase in the rates that webcasters, including Pandora, must pay record companies for the next five years may have huge consequences for Pandora’s business.
articles.abstract: An increase in the rates that webcasters, including Pandora, must pay record companies for the next five years may have huge consequences for Pandora’s business.
articles.lead_paragraph: Since it began 10 years ago, Pandora Media has become one of the most popular digital music services in the world, with around 80 million regular users. But it has never had a profitable year, its user growth has slowed and lately Wall Street has become impatient.

articles.headline: A Climate Deal, 6 Fateful Years in the Making
articles.snippet: The story of how the deal came together started long before that — in December 2009, with the failure of the last such summit meeting in Copenhagen.
articles.abstract: The story of how the deal came together started long before that — in December 2009, with the failure of the last such summit meeting in Copenhagen.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — It took almost two weeks for negotiators from 195 countries to finally pass the landmark climate accord this weekend after several espresso-fueled all-nighters and long, passionate debates over the meaning of a single word, such as “shall.”

articles.headline: The Engineering of Volkswagen’s Aggressive Ambition
articles.snippet: As Volkswagen struggles to explain a globe-spanning emissions-cheating scandal, its management culture — confident, cutthroat and insular — is coming under scrutiny.
articles.abstract: As Volkswagen struggles to explain a globe-spanning emissions-cheating scandal, its management culture — confident, cutthroat and insular — is coming under scrutiny.
articles.lead_paragraph: WOLFSBURG, Germany — All cars at the headquarters should, according to the rules, be parked facing the same way. The firm is controlled by a tight-knit troika of a billionaire family (Ferdinand Porsche’s descendants), a German state government (Lower Saxony) and powerful labor unions. The corporate jet is not just any jet, but a full-size Airbus.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Graham Bowley

articles.headline: Climate Deal Is Signal to Industry: The Era of Carbon Reduction Is Here
articles.snippet: The world economy has a long way to go to break away from the use of coal and oil that fueled progress since the Industrial Revolution.
articles.abstract: The world economy has a long way to go to break away from the use of coal and oil that fueled progress since the Industrial Revolution.
articles.lead_paragraph: With the ink barely dry on a landmark climate accord, nations now face an even more daunting challenge: how to get their industries to go along.
articles.byline: By Clifford Krauss and Keith Bradsher

articles.headline: In Virtual Reality Headsets, Investors Glimpse the Future
articles.snippet: Venture capital is pouring into virtual reality start-ups, as proponents of the technology extol its potential to transform entertainment, communications and work.
articles.abstract: Venture capital is pouring into virtual reality start-ups, as proponents of the technology extol its potential to transform entertainment, communications and work.
articles.lead_paragraph: Magic Leap, a secretive company making wearable technology for mixing digital imagery with the real world, is seeking to raise $827 million. Jaunt, maker of a 3-D camera for filming virtual reality video, has nabbed a total of $100 million, including $65 million in September. And 8i, which makes technology that lets people interact with video of humans as though they were in the same room, has raised nearly $15 million.

articles.headline: Junk Bond Fund’s Chief Departs After Blocking Withdrawals
articles.snippet: Third Avenue said in a statement that David M. Barse and the investment firm “have mutually agreed to separate.”
articles.abstract: Third Avenue said in a statement that David M. Barse and the investment firm “have mutually agreed to separate.”
articles.lead_paragraph: When the prominent Wall Street investor Martin J. Whitman finally stepped down from running Third Avenue Management in 2012, the move was seen as an inevitable passing of the torch for the octogenarian fund manager.

articles.headline: Why Very Low Interest Rates May Stick Around
articles.snippet: A 200-year history shows that the real aberration looks like the 7.3 percent average experienced in the U.S. from 1970 to 2007.
articles.abstract: A 200-year history shows that the real aberration looks like the 7.3 percent average experienced in the U.S. from 1970 to 2007.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve will most likely raise interest rates this week for the first time in nearly a decade. To understand what it means — and doesn’t mean — consider a previous year in which interest rates were on the rise.
